definitions.definition: exert force on (someone or something), typically by taking hold of them, in order to move or try to move them toward oneself or the origin of the force.
examples: he pulled them down onto the couch
synonyms: wrench; informalyank "he pulled the box toward him"

definitions.definition: (of an animal or vehicle) be attached to the front and be the source of forward movement of (a vehicle).
examples: the carriage was pulled by four horses

definitions.definition: take hold of and exert force on (something) so as to move it from a specified position or in a specified direction.
examples: she pulled a handkerchief out of her pocket
synonyms: remove "he pulled the bad tooth out"

definitions.definition: bring out (a weapon) to attack or threaten someone.
examples: it's not every day a young woman pulls a gun on a burglar

definitions.definition: inhale deeply while smoking (a pipe or cigar).
damage (a muscle, ligament, etc.) by abnormal strain.
examples: strain, sprain, wrench, turn, tear; damage she pulled a muscle

definitions.definition: print (a proof).
retrieve (an item of data) from the top of a stack.
(of a vehicle or person) move steadily in a specified direction or to reach a specified point.
examples: the bus was about to pull away

definitions.definition: move in a specified direction with effort, especially by taking hold of something and exerting force.
examples: he pulled himself into the saddle

definitions.definition: move one's body in a specified direction, especially against resistance.
examples: she tried to pull away from him

definitions.definition: (of an engine) exert propulsive force; deliver power.
examples: the engine warmed up quickly and pulled well

definitions.definition: work oars to cause a boat to move.
examples: he pulled at the oars, and the boat moved swiftly through the water

definitions.definition: cause (someone) to patronize, buy, or show interest in something; attract.
examples: tourist attractions that pull in millions of foreign visitors

definitions.definition: carry out or achieve (something requiring skill, luck, or planning).
examples: the magazine pulled its trick of producing the right issue at the right time

definitions.definition: cancel or withdraw (an entertainment or advertisement).
examples: the gig was pulled at the first sign of difficulty

definitions.definition: withdraw (a player) from a game.
examples: four of the leading eight runners were pulled

definitions.definition: check the speed of (a horse), especially so as to make it lose a race.
strike (a ball) in the direction of one's follow-through so that it travels to the left or, with a left-handed player, to the right.
examples: he pulled the ball every time he hit a grounder

definitions.definition: (of a lineman) withdraw from position and cross parallel to and behind the line of scrimmage to block opposing players for a runner.
an act of taking hold of something and exerting force to draw it toward one.
examples: give the hair a quick pull, and it comes out by the roots
synonyms: heave; informalyank "give the chain a pull"

definitions.definition: a handle to hold while pulling.
examples: the Cowboy Collection offers hand-forged iron drawer pulls

definitions.definition: a deep draft of a drink.
examples: he unscrewed the cap from the flask and took another pull

definitions.definition: an act of sucking at a cigar or pipe.
examples: he took a pull on his cheroot

definitions.definition: an injury to a muscle or ligament caused by abnormal strain.
examples: he was taken out of the game with a hamstring pull

definitions.definition: a printer's proof.
a force drawing someone or something in a particular direction or course of action.
examples: the pull of the water tore her away

definitions.definition: something exerting an influence or attraction.
examples: one of the pulls of urban life is the opportunity of finding work
synonyms: appeal "she felt the pull of the sea"

definitions.definition: the condition of being able to exercise influence.
examples: they were hamstrung without the political pull of the mayor's office
synonyms: clout "he has a lot of pull in finance"
